Posts.Content: Ol' Line Rebel is absolutely giving excellent advice. Get in to see a doctor ASAP. This has the sounds of inflammatory breast cancer. PLEASE let us know what is happening. Do not let a doctor blow you off, you need some in depth tests now. Big hugs, and get help immediately! Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Should I be worried!

Posts.Content: Honeywest, such is modern medicine.... YOU have done the correct and right thing. You didn't give up until you got an answer. If they only knew how much anxiety this lack of communication gives their patients. I could go on but leave it as you have to be your own best advocate when it comes to your medical care. OK so the words and findings that earned you furter testing is "new nodule" and "irregular asymmetries". The rest of the words are just refurring to the location the "the thing." Sometimes calcifications will earn you an extra trip but now in your case. The rest of the report sounds very reassuring. Since your breast tissue is "moderately dense" it makes getting a clear mammogram a bit more difficult. You will have your ultrasound and they will tell you if what they see warrants a biopsy. Even if they do..... do not lose-your-breakfast, as they want to make sure about what "the thing" is. I am at an age where (old-as-dirt) where my pals have "things in mammograms" commonly. I am the only one who have a "thing" turn out to be "something". Keep in mind, odds are in your favor. Please keep us posted. I am so glad you had a little edge to your voicemail. It does wonders... Hang in there, you did good girl! Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Further testing after Mammogram

Posts.Content: Honey.... GREAT POLICY! The wait is so freakin' terrifying, I don't know why this isn't the practice... (oh yes.... no time) Since I have had breast cancer when I go in for my yearly mammogram, I get the results before I leave.... breast cancer has it's privledges. I am glad for your sake you will know Monday. You will get to watch the ultrasound and the tech will point out the area. I had a radiologist do my ultrasound and she was very good about explaining what she was seeing. Thanks for letting me know. I bet you will be ok and Monday will bring a big sigh of relief! Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Further testing after Mammogram

Posts.Content: Honey, I KNEW you would be OK!!!!!! I am so glad to hear that and know the great relief you are feeling. Yes, I had breast cancer 5 years ago and remain cancer free. I have an annual mammogram of my remaining breast. I also have an MRI (my request) because it would show any abnormality at it's smallest point. I also take a hormone blocking drug because my tumor was hormone positive... which was a good thing. I had the most common type of breast cancer which was also a good thing. My doctor told me at least I have the "good kind of breast cancer." I really want other women to know breast cancer is not a death sentence. I also want other women to know how important it is to have regular mammograms and to do regular breast self checks. I found my own breast cancer 7 months after my regular mammogram. It was early stage, I chose to have a mastectomy but I could have had a lumpectomy. I also had to have chemotherapy and I never had a bit of nausea... just felt like I had the flu for about 4 days after the treatment. I just marched through everything with a positive attitude and a big sense of humor. I am so glad you are ok. We are living in a wonderful time where so much can be done to cure breast cancer. Diagnostics, surgery, treatments, have become so much better. The key to it all is early diagnosis. It's bad enough to find out you have breast cancer but to find it at a later stage is really lousy. Keep up with your mammograms and do not live in fear. Wonderful to talk to you and so glad you are ok! Hugs and take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Further testing after Mammogram

Posts.Content: We are bombarded with health information all the time... especially breast cancer warnings. It is terrifying to realize you have one of those ---warning signs---. So many women recognize they have a lump in their breast or other such things that just happen and then we find outselves being terrified. We have to wait for an appointment, and if there is any testing we have to wait again for the outcome. It is horrible to find yourself in that situation. First of all, this isn't something new, most of these --things-- turn out to be non-cancerous. The only thing I would push you to do is ask the doctor to be referred for a mammogram and possibly an ultrasound. Sometimes doctor's have a tendency to blow-you-off and poo-poo your fear. Doctor's are not always correct. I would rather have a test that is real proof things are ok rather than having the doctor snickering at me. Young women do get breast cancer. You want to make darn sure, this inverted nipple is not a "southbound freight train" coming at you in the future. I wish I could take away the fear you feel.... been there, done that because I am old enough to be your grandmother. We are always surrounded by people who have illnesses and you can't help but think --it could be you. Chances are.... it WON'T be but until you go in to see that doctor, you are stuck in a scary spot. Just try to keep busy with that new little guy of yours. Pretend .... you are NOT worried for his sake. Hang in there, your appointment will get here. If that doctor poo-poo's you and says "Little lady, there's nothing wrong with that breast" you ask him, politely... "How do you KNOW?" Take care, and hug your darling little boy. Sharon
Posts.Title: inverted nipple!!!

Posts.Content: Honeywest, it is very common to have-to-come-back-for-further bla-bla. It could be something as simple as another mammogram because it wasn't readable. It could also be they need to do an ultrasound because they want to see the consistancy of something seen on the mammogram. I absolutely have been through this more than I can count and it does not get any easier. Of course, it is over the weekend so you have a worry about it. 9 times out of 10, these come back as nothing horrible. Doctors are so concerned they check everything!!! If they still have questions, they may even want a needle biopsy. That's when you normally start wetting your pants with fear.... but again..... most of the time they come back nothing horrible. I have also had breast cancer so I know what it's like to get that lousy phone call but I am alive, well, cancer-free. Try not to worry but I know there is a part of you that will. All I can say is, you have kept up with your mammograms and are doing your part. Chances are in your favor, nothing it wrong. As for changing mammogram places.... YOU BET.... things CAN get screwed up. You make sure you ask questions as so checking to see your mammogram is truly YOUR'S. My doctor read one of my blood tests incorrectly and was going to send me in for a bunch of horrendous liver tests. I am the one that discovered he had mixed up two tests and read them in the wrong sequence. You are your own best advocate and you have to not put all of your trust that things will be just perfect. I always make sure and ask questions.... politely if I have any misgivings. Please keep us posted about your further testing but I bet things are just fine. Hang in there.... take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Further testing after Mammogram

Posts.Content: I am glad you are getting this checked out. It is difficult to say if one is related to the other. Usually the way it goes is a mammogram, and then if something suspicious is seen on the mammogram then an ultrasound is done. If a lump still can't be identified, you will then have a biopsy. I know you are concerned about breast cancer but there are many other non-cancerous things it could be. As for the back and chest pain, it can be stress, muscle strain, etc. You are probably really focusing on this discomfort which can heighten it even more. You are probably unconciously holding tension in your shoulders, back, chest muscles.... I do this myself. You are taking the right steps to identify what the lump is. Be sure to mention the chest and back pain but it probably isn't related to breast lump. Do you have any family history, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, of breast cancer? Please let us know what you find out. It is always a good thing to have anything out of the ordinary checked out just like you are doing. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Breast Lump and Pain around lower back and ribs

Posts.Content: Shellie, thank you for sharing your story... I am new to this board but have had breast cancer. My breast cancer was also missed by my yearly mammogram and I found a lump 7 months after my "clear" outcome. I was being checked in a breast diagnostic center in a large city but my breasts were also dense so I am sure the cancer had been missed by a year or two. Your story and mine are not that uncommon. Mammograms are not infallable. My advise to any woman who has dense breast tissue and has any kind of pain or something out of the ordinary needs to demand an MRI or some other diagnostic tool. When I finally had an MRI, the cancer showed up like a light bulb. I was diagnosed with Stage 2B IDC 1 node positive. ER+ PR+ Her2-. Mastectomy, 4 rounds of AC chemo, and 5 years of hormone blocking Femara. You and I did what we were supposed to do and the medical community failed us. I have found.... and I know you have too, you have to be your own best advocate. We are far from alone in this. I know another woman on another board who was also mis-diagnosed and she is going through treatment for her Stage 3C breast cancer. Shellie, I am sure we have many "sisters" out there who could add to the stories. I hope there comes a time when an MRI is a standard for women with dense breast tissue. Thanks again for bringing up your story. It allowed me to "vent" my frustration. How are you doing now? I am coming up on my 5 year anniversary and will complete the hormone blocking therapy in January. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: My breast cancer WAS PAINFUL thus delaying diagnosis!!

Posts.Content: SO sorry to hear you are trapped in this personal hell. There is nothing worse that the wait. By the time you receive this you will know the outcome. I will never forget the day I heard the outcome of my biopsy. Unfortunately, the office had no problem, curtly, telling me "You have breast cancer.... sorry, the doctor can't see you for 3 weeks." It was a horror I thought I would wake up from, but didn't. Please let us know how you are. At least, you will not be living in suspense for yet another 6 months. I am glad you chose to do the biopsy. I can assure you, knowing, is much better, no matter what the outcome, than being in the purgatory of not knowing. Take care..... Sharon
Posts.Title: Will not give biopsy results on the phone

Posts.Content: I completely agree.... if this has been a long time thing it is probably ok. I also had an inverted nipple for several years, in my case, I eventually found out I had breast cancer. It is something to be watched. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: inverted nipple!!!

Posts.Content: I am so glad to hear from you. Honestly, I have been thinking about you since I read your post. I will be sending positive thoughts and prayers your way. Please let us know how you are doing. I can share with you my sister-in-law had a node in her neck that ended up being benign. No guess what caused it so hopefully, this will turn out to be just some weird inflammatory response to a "bug". Big hugs to you and take care, I will keep all good stuff heading your way. Sharon
Posts.Title: Should I be worried!

Posts.Content: THANK GOD!!!! Doesn't it feel as if the weight of the world has been lifted off of your shoulders? We are ALL celebrating with you. It just shows.... most of these things are not cancer. BUT.... now you know FOR SURE. I am so happy for you. YAHOOOOO! Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Will not give biopsy results on the phone

Posts.Content: I agree with Jane.... so often these are nothing more than a benign condition that can happen to any of us. You are so very smart to have this checked out as soon as you can get an appointment. I with I had a way of taking away your worry but don't. Doctor's are so careful about going to great lengths to make sure this is benign. This adds even more worry because this can go all the way to the biopsy point. By then, many women have themselves convinced they have breast cancer..... NOT TRUE! I have a lot of friends who have had a ba-zillion biopsy's. I am the ONLY one who turned out to actually have breast cancer. So, do not go to the dark side if your doctor says you have to get a biopsy. They are just being very, very, careful. Hang in there, I bet you are going to be just fine. BUT..... doctor's have to do their job. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Painful lumo under nipple

Posts.Content: I completely understand your fear and want to tell you every woman I know have had this twinge of panic at least once to many times in their lives. We are just lumpy creatures and some more than others. First of all, doctors are extremely careful about not just trusting what they feel on a physical exam. They would be --nearly-- convinced it is nothing to be worried about but to cover "all their bases" they refer you for a mammogram and ultrasound. I would not worry so much because the vast majority of these lumps and bumps turn out to be benign. This is very standard good practice by your doctor to refer you. Don't even get too ruffled if your doctor asks for a biopsy. Every one of my friends have been referred for multiple testing on various breast lumps and I am the only one who turned out to have breast cancer.... I have a LOT of friends. I would just stay busy, and try to push these negative thoughts out of your head. This will probably turn out to be ok. You have already done the right thing by having these lumps checked. Your doctor, in turn, treated you correctly by referring you for further testing, just to make sure. Please keep us posted and I bet this will be ok. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: prominent areolar duct? scared

Posts.Content: A GREAT BIG SIGH OF RELIEF! I am very happy for you and wish every woman would be as careful as you are. Good for you and I knew it would turn out OK. Thanks for letting us know. Keep checking and wonderful health to you! Happy Trails, Sharon
Posts.Title: prominent areolar duct? scared

Posts.Content: I am completely with my "sisters" on this one. Call the doctor asap there are a bunch of things this could be, and will, no doubt, turn out to be something benign, but annoying. We are also dancing around the gorilla-in-the-livingroom. That is inflammatory breast cancer. It is a very rare but very aggressive enemy. It is so rare, some doctor's, outside of the breast cancer world have never seen it. It is nothing to mess with. It does not show up on a mammogram or an ultrasound. As far as I know, a biopsy is the most frequent way it is diagnosed. My money is on this being an allergic response to something in your enviroment.... but get it checked as soon as you can. Please, keep us posted. Sharon
Posts.Title: Rash and hard breast

Posts.Content: I home you have had the biopsy by now. I just signed up for this board yesterday. Please let us know how you are doing and what the resulf of your test was. So many of these things are benign. Hang in there, I know how scared you are. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Someone, please help me... horrified to go back for spot compression and ultrasound 1 2

Posts.Content: The 17th is an eternity when you are waiting for something like this. Radiologists see these things all the time, so I would take comfort in those words. When I went in for a biopsy, the radiologist told me to plan on it coming back as cancer. She was right. As for moving up the appointment, I would call the office each morning to ask if there was a cancellation. You never know, you may get lucky and snag an earlier appointment. Keep in mind, it usually takes about 3 days to get test results back. One more thing, I found the lump in my breast 7 months after my annual mammogram. It felt like cauliflower under my skin. It felt uneven, and the edges were also uneven. There wasn't a smooth place on it. When I felt it, it was weird, clearly unlike any other lump I had felt in my breast. I hope you can set this worry aside. Most of these lumps are benign, this is small, the radiologist did not think it looked suspicious. When you have scary thoughts creeping into your mind, crowd them out with the more positive facts. Hang in there, I hope you let us know how it turns out. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Someone, please help me... horrified to go back for spot compression and ultrasound 1 2

Posts.Content: I can see why you will have to wait... since the doctor isn't going to be in town. Another reason the radiologist is being so careful is because you have had a family member with breast cancer. It sounds like your Mom had great care and she is doing well today because of it. It is difficult to have to wait and I really wish there was a magic answer I could give you to help get you through this time. Hang in there and there is a good chance this is not going to have a bad outcome. Blessings to you, Sharon
Posts.Title: Someone, please help me... horrified to go back for spot compression and ultrasound 1 2

Posts.Content: I had surgery in 2007.
Posts.Title: Someone, please help me... horrified to go back for spot compression and ultrasound 1 2

Posts.Content: Every place has a different criteria for recommending biopsy's. For whatever reason, you fit into that recommendation. I know exactly how you are feeling.... terror, panic, and being driven crazy by the "what-if's" that won't leave you alone. There are all sorts of benign things this could be. The radiologist, who has looked at many "things" has to be 100% sure this isn't BC. The radiologist could be doing this biopsy more out of covering his/her be-hind rather than worrying this is BC. Hang in there.... and I'd bug them for an earlier appointment. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Someone, please help me... horrified to go back for spot compression and ultrasound 1 2

Posts.Content: I would highly recommend getting an MRI. It can show things no mammogram or ultrasound has the ability to show. I get one every year. I have to pay for it but it is at a reduced rate and they let me pay it off a little at a time. It is truly the gold-standard of diagnostics and it showed my breast cancer like no other machine! If I would have demanded an MRI earlier, my breast cancer would have been diagnosed at a much smaller less advanced stage. PLEASE follow through with the MRI. Often times, it can show if cancer has moved into lymph nodes. My husband and I are far from rich and we have lousy insurance but this is my life.... get the MRI. Sharon
Posts.Title: Someone, please help me... horrified to go back for spot compression and ultrasound 1 2

Posts.Content: I am glad you checked this out with your doctor and by now you have had a mammogram. It is difficult to say if these random sensations that occure are a sign of something bad. Having had breast cancer, the breast affected did have sensations.... itching, tingling. I, too, had regular mammograms and ultrasounds that didn't show anything.... until I felt a lump. It is so important for women to be aware of their bodies. What is normal and what isn't. Realistically, you can't keep running back to the doctor with each tiny little thing. It is so vital you do monthly self-breast exams, the same time each month. This is how I found my breast cancer even after regular mammograms. The mammogram and U/S never picked up this cancer. Take a look at the symptoms of breast cancer, if you feel there is something in question do not hesitate to have it checked. This is especially important since you have breast cancer in your family. I did NOT but still got breast cancer. You have to be on top of things and realize there are certain breast cancer that do not present as a lump. Just know your body, and question something that has changed. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Breast Tingling sensation

Posts.Content: One more thing..... PLEASE.... EVERYBODY.... when you get a test result written in "greek" do not be afraid to call the radiologist back and have them translate. I have found so many people will suffer, needlessly because they don't thing they "should or can" call to ask questions. If the radiologist can't speak to you, a technician can. You will then be able to ask any questions you have at that time. It will take away a lot of the terror of the unknown. Sharon
Posts.Title: Someone, please help me... horrified to go back for spot compression and ultrasound 1 2

Posts.Content: So many women get this little "greetings" by phone or in the mail. All they want to do is take more views of the breast in question and do a compression which will flatten out the area a bit more and allow the mammogram to penetrate the dense tissue. A "0" birad is the lowest grade number. Birad grades go from 0 to 6. 0 means the exam was incomplete and they need more views to complete the mammogram exam. They may need to do an ultrasound if they still can't get a view. This happens so very often with younger women. They have dense breast tissue and it can be challenging to get a clear mammogram. It turns out very cloudy, or white on the film and reading it with any degree of certainty is difficult if not impossible. Do you know if the machine used was a digital? They have a better chance of getting clearer shots through dense breast tissue. They may still have to do an ultrasound to tell what they are looking at. In some cases.... they might even do a needle biopsy. PLEASE.... even if they go to something like that, this does NOT mean you have breast cancer! Your tissue is just so dense, they can't tell what they are looking at. I have a lot of friends who have had needle biopsy's.... only one turn out positive and that was me. That means a lot of doctors are being very careful to do a complete exam so they can positively identify this as benign. There are ba-zillions of women who have these kind of benign findings every single day. Only a small percentage of these women actually turn out to have breast cancer.... and I mean S-M-A-L-L. Please try not to worry. Chances are, this is a very painful cyst but they have to make sure. There is nothing in your report that would set off alarm bells to me. Absolutely.... take your husband with you to your next appointment. If you do have to have an ultrasound.... it would be good to have him right in the room with you so the findings can be explained to both of you. Chances are great.... you are going to be just fine. The older you get, the weirder boobs can look on a mammogram. Please keep us posted. Try not to worry.... take a deep breath, hang in there and take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Two Partially Obscured Densities Visualized

Posts.Content: I KNEW you would be ok. It is terrifying to get the contact that something doesn't look quite right. I am very happy for you and know you feel as if the weight of the world has been removed from your shoulders. Celebrate life! Thanks for letting me know. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Two Partially Obscured Densities Visualized

Posts.Content: It is impossible to take even a guess at what this could be. You are doing the correct thing in getting this checked out. One isn't necessarily connected to the other. I would put breast cancer way down on the list of --probabilities--. You could be doing some kind of repetitive movement that causes your back pain. As for the lump under your arm, could be your body filtering some kind of infection through your lymph system. Again, you are doing all the right things in getting it checked out. Let us know, and take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: upper left back pain and found lump unders skin in armpit

Posts.Content: If I were to choose any test, it would be an MRI. In my case, it was the test that really showed I had breast cancer. I don't know how many false positives.... that could be a rumor that has grown-legs. The dye injected for an MRI is taken up by breast cancer tumor which are usually rich with blood supply. In my case, my 2.2cm tumor looked like a light bulb. I went to the clinic in which the doctor who developled MRI for breast cancer diagnosis. I got to talk to him personally about MRI's and my case in particular. He pointed out so many things in my MRI and I could totally see the significance in getting this test. I was diagnosed with invasive ductal cancer stage 2B with one node positive. He gave me a lot of information that was much more comfort and reasurance, that than horror about the diagnosis. I just worry about wait and see. I still don't think you have enough information and am convinced since you are so worried. I would be too so I completely understand your fear and feel you are justified. I would get an appointment with the radiologist and discuss your concerns. Since you have had breast cancer, I would get a consult with your oncologist and possibly surgeon. I am surprised the radiologist place isn't giving you quicker results. The place I go, I do not leave until I get my mammogram results. Same thing with the ultrasound. I totally get it.... think it's a nightmare. Keep us posted... Sharon
Posts.Title: Total nightmare

Posts.Content: What I find doctor's are more inclined to do additional testing just to be safe. The negative's is it makes women worry. Having had breast cancer, I would welcome this further investigation as my breast cancer was missed for 7 months. This IS NOT to say you need to be more worried than you already are. Your doctor is taking the correct and prudent approach. Most of these things turn out to be not cancerous but they have to cover their bases. They probably have a criteria for doing further testing on ''things" they find. You probably fall in to those parameters. Nobody knows what this is, for sure, until they look at cells under a microscope. Hang in there, I am sure this will be fine and a lot of worry for nothing. BUT.... your doctor is doing right by you. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Help with Breast Ultrasound

Posts.Content: I am very happy to hear from you but oh so sad you have joined the club....:-( You WILL get through this but I can't imagine throwing a wedding on top of all of it! Having been through breast cancer and a wedding.... NOT all at the same time.... your plate will be full. Of COURSE the impact of losing a boob, hair, is a big one because it is a visible statement of what you are going through. I must say after having gone through where you are going, "the hair" thing is a bummer. You DO get through it. I would suggest you take this one step at a time. FIRST & FOREMOST, embrace your beautiful wedding and your wonderful husband. Try to shove the next few months out of your mind for right now. You already know what will be happening so don't concern yourself with the breast cancer. When those thoughts creep into your mind, shove them out and focus on your new life. This IS a new life! This may sound odd but I am happy.... if you had to have cancer.... this did not turn out to be a "mets" from your lung cancer. This is different and caught at an early stage. Your CT & bone scans are clear which is a life-affirming celebration in itself. Honestly.... even with a diagnosis of breast cancer, you do have a lot to be happy for. I hope to hear from you again and really will help you along your journey even if it is from half way around the world. I always think of fellow breast cancer ladies as sisters. Your job right now is to enjoy your lovely wedding and really your new life. Hang in there.... take care, your "sister" Sharon
Posts.Title: nearly time for my mastectomy

Posts.Content: I am SOOOOO THRILLED to hear from you! It sounds like you have come through it quite well, considering. Yes, once that drain is out, you will feel just that much better. You have certainly started your marriage off with a bang.... it is one of those "For Better, For Worse". For you, it can be said.... "For Worse....and for a LOT BETTER!" As for your sweetie and his kind words about not wanting you to have to go through more surgery... you can tell he is in it for the "long haul." I didn't have reconstruction and have been happy with my fake-boobie. Even though I had a very easy time with the mastectomy, I just didn't want any more surgery. I also kept hearing about the expanders being painful and it is a long process. It is all a personal choice and you need to do what works for you. I am just so glad to hear you are done with the mastectomy and are definitely on the mend. PLEASE keep me posted. I have thought about you and your wedding AND your surgery! There are not many who can answer the question... "What'd you do for your honeymoon?" with "Oh, I had a mastectomy!" Hang in there.... and you tell your wonderful husband he is one of the world's most wonderful men. Huge healing hugs to you, & take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: coping well after my matectomy!!!

Posts.Content: I am SO sorry you have gone without some kind of an answer. Hopefully by now, you have had the biopsy and all is fine. SO many of these --abnormal-- things turn out ok. The ultrasound showed a mass and the consistancy and location is being explained. Please let us know if you have had your biopsy yet. The wait for any of these procedures and outcomes seems endless! I wish there was a faster way. You are among many, many, women who are going through the same thing day after day. Hang in there.... take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Abnormal ultrasound

Posts.Content: sorry... double post.
Posts.Title: Two Partially Obscured Densities Visualized

Posts.Content: Been there, done that.... Universally, waiting for this type of test result is like torture. In my case, I didn't have to wait long as the dr. doing the biopsy told me to expect mine to be breast cancer. No surprise when I received the call. Thankfully, most lumps are not cancer. I have reached the 5 year mark.... healthy, and cancer free. I hope and pray you a benign finding. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: waiting for biopsy

Posts.Content: To make absolutely sure what you are dealing with and to put your mind at ease, I would insist on a biopsy. It is a quick procedure where they numb the area, and withdraw some cells from the spot. You will feel pressure when they insert the needle but you will then know, for sure, what you are dealing with. I can understand your worry about this because they really can't give you a --for sure-- answer. Please keep us posted. Rest assured, you have done what you should up to this point. I would go get the biopsy. The only other thing you could do is ask for an MRI. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: 27yrs old: grape size lump: breastfeeding

Posts.Content: Your feelings and fear are completely understandible and normal. Every woman who finds an unusual lump has the same fears. You must not let these fears stop you from being seen by a breast specialist. Talking to them on the phone will not help you with the bottom line. They cannot tell you what this lump is without an exam and testing. What will happen.... they will order a mammogram, possibly an ultrasound, and from that you may have to have a needle biopsy. Even if you have to have a needle biopsy, this DOES NOT MEAN you have breast cancer! I have had many friends have to have biopsy's and not one turned up with breast cancer..... only me. Chances are good, this is not beast cancer but you have to be seen. A mammogram is an e-ray of your breast. An ultrasound is a painless look at the lump using a wand that sends sound waves and projects a view of the lump on a screen to try to see what it is made of. A needle biopsy entails numbing the area and getting a sample of the lump to view under a microscope. You will be scared until you get the results back BUT do not let this fear paralyze you into doing nothing. FORGET trying to talk to a doctor before you make an appointment put on your big girl panties and call for the next available time to be seen. You have had a lot of medical stuff happen in your life but putting these restrictions from your fear is not going to make this go away. The stress of not knowing what this is will only make your depression worse. You have got to be stronger than your fear and you CAN. You HAVE to be seen, that is the bottom line. You will then be doing what you need to do to take care of yourself properly. Keep in mind MOST of these lumps and bumps turn out to be NOT breast cancer! Hang in there, no more drama about this.... call the surgeon's office and get yourself seen. You can talk to the doctor when you are in their office. Great big hugs for courage and strength. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Found a lump near the nipple of left breast.

Posts.Content: Oh Harmony, I am so sorry to hear this and can completely understand why you are so worried. Are they going to do a biopsy of the area or just watch it? Your terror antenna are up for a perfectly good reason. If I were you... I would get an MRI, and if needed, an appointment with your oncologist or your surgeon. Information is power and the unknown is the most terrifying. Waiting for the other shoe to drop isn't a good way to live life. I would ask for an MRI because of the denseness of the breast tissue. I would be as pro-active as you can be. It is scary but you are in control. You put on those big girl panties and be your own best advocate. Do not cower from this challenge hit it head-on. You have got to get some better answers and relieve your anxiety. Start with the radiologist asking what are the chances of this turning out like the other side? Be demanding about an MRI.... if there is cancer, it will light it up like a Christmas tree bulb and be found at a much earlier stage. If it is clear.... YAHOO! and go shopping! I get an MRI every year just because I want to be ahead of things if I have a recurrance. Am I terrified??? ABSOLUTELY but I don't want to sit back and watch it get me. Hang in there Harmony..... please go out and get more information. Blessing's Sharon
Posts.Title: Total nightmare

Posts.Content: I think it would be very wise to this biopsied in some way. Your doctor is right to be concerned. Having no relatives with breast cancer is no guarantee you will escape breast cancer. I had no relatives either side who have even had cancer. I had breast cancer 5 years ago. There is no way anyone can tell what this is without a biopsy to look at this on a cell level. It will probably turn out to be nothing but if it is breast cancer.... you want to catch it as soon as possible. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Bloody nipple discharge

Posts.Content: Unfortunately, I do not have the specific answer for you so what I am about to say is how you --might-- go about finding the information that you need. I would start by looking on the Internet just by doing a simple --search-- of breast cancer treatment in Chennai and the larger cities in Singapore. I did a search and was able to find much information rather quickly. You may have to then contact these centers to ask about specific costs. Rest assured, you could start a good search that would help you in your query. Another suggestion I would schedule a consultation with her doctor, hopefully an oncologist. We are lucky to all be connected with communication at our fingertips via the Internet. Doctors are on top of that list. They have sources for information about care in different countries. The most important thing for your mom is getting competent care no matter where she goes. You should be able to find excellent care in each country. and there are, well known, cancer centers. Breast cancer treatment can be extended, and extensive. Lastly, hopefully people reading this board will have the answers you need in finding treatment for your mom. Good luck to you and your mom.
Posts.Title: Cancer treatment costs - Singapore and India

Posts.Content: FIrst and foremost, I MUST tell you how absolutely thrilled I am to hear you did not settle for what the first surgeon said to you or how he blew you off. So many women (or men) would have just walked out... with the "unknown lump" and just try to forget about it. Until there is some kind of biopsy.... NO ONE knows what it is. Chances are it will be ok but, honestly, I would request a biopsy. That is the only way to know, for sure, what type of cells are in that lump. You are a very intelligent, and brave women for charging ahead in your quest to find out what this it. In the medical world, you have to be your own best advocate! You are steller in your approach and courage! Hang in there, stand your ground, love yourself enough to, kindly, ask/demand the procedure that will clearly identify what this is. Take care, Sharon (you get the Gold Star Award!!!)
Posts.Title: A lump under my right armpit

Posts.Content: Take it from one who had a breast cancer missed.... you are doing the right thing. Hang tough and get it checked out. This will probably come back as something NOT terrible but you will never regret, truly, finding out what this really is. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: A lump under my right armpit

Posts.Content: Stay off the internet, or just don't read the medical stuff. You can drive yourself into a very dark place.... been there, done that. Don't put yourself down so much. You have a right to your feelings. Hang in there.... make that list to discuss with your doctor. Do not start off you doctor appointment with a negative statement like.... "Maybe I am just imagining this...." Rather... say something like.... "I am not imagining these swollen lymph nodes...!!!" Put on your "big girl panties" march in there and find out what the cat-hair is going on!!! Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: A lump under my right armpit

Posts.Content: I understand what you are saying. You weren't given a reason for the cyst and the swollen lymph nodes. If you are also having other symptoms, like the fatigue, your body is trying to fight something. It also sounds like you feel like you are being blown-off by your hubby and doctor's. They dismiss your symptoms. You may have to start fresh and go to another doctor... maybe an internist. Before you go, make a list of your symptoms, how long they have been going on, and the medications you take. Be clear, and concise. Honestly, you have to be your own best advocate when it comes to medical care. Do not have the attitude of "this is all in your head." If it is.... that can also be treated and even that is nothing to laugh about. Depression can lead to a lowered immune and cause you to get sick. Your "gut" is telling you something is going on, you still have not had any kind of clarification and it is bothering you. All of it may just boil down to some kind of virus but you are still worried. I'd say you still have some doors to knock on before you find some answers that will give you peace of mind. Do not let the people around you make you feel like you are being silly. Put on those "big girl panties" and find a doctor who will give you some answers. Hang in there... Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: A lump under my right armpit

Posts.Content: I completely understand your angst! I almost see a tinge if girl-guilt but if you are worried, you can't help it. Until you get the explanation of "WHY" & "WHAT'S UP" this worry will be with you. Yes, I did have breast cancer and found out when I was 59, in 2006. It was early stage, I went through treatment and am perfectly healthy. As my picture shows, I returned to my passion in life which is horses. This photo was taken about two months after I had finished chemo. (I am still bald under that helmet of mine) Of course, as a celebration, I entered a horse show with one of my mini horses. I think why I am so adamant for you is because I was mis-diagnosed. The breast center told me my mammogram was clear. I found a lump 7 months after that mammogram and my breast cancer ended up being a 2B. If if would have been found at that mammogram check up, it would have been even smaller. So.... I am all for anyone to keep digging until they get an explanation! Now... this is NOT to say you are looking for breast cancer. I think your problem probably stems from some kind of virus condition BUT your worry is affecting your quality of life and peace of mind. You need some answers. I think you are getting the impression from those around you that your worry is being dismissed as silly. Your gut is saying you still need to find some answers. This is your body's means of survival. Do not keep apologizing because you have a basic human instinct to LIVE. You ARE doing the right thing... you need to find out why you have these swollen lymph nodes and the "cyst". You just put on those "big girl warrior panties" and go get your answer. I am cheering for you! Hang in there, take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: A lump under my right armpit

Posts.Content: There are several things these could be that are NOT cancer. Just like Ginger says, it could be little flecks of calcium, it could be benign cysts, or any number of things. So many more of these biopsies turn out to be nothing and these are also incredibly tiny. Your doctor is just being really proactive which is great. I have had cancer also so I can completely understand why you are very scared but try not to make yourself sick. Waiting for tests is so difficult and it is like your life takes a detour until your test comes back. Please let us know how it turns out. Hang in there & take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: core biopsy

Posts.Content: Kayla, you are at one of the best of the best places (Cleveland Clinic) so you can be sure you are in good hands with the diagnostic tests you will be having. As for the lesions on your pancreas, I would imagine, if it were something serious, you would have had some kind of symptoms by now. You should bring up to your doctor but I would think you would be sick.... or worse by now. Colon or pancreatic cancer doesn't metastasize to the breast....thankfully! Yes, you are correct, breast tissue changes with time. When are you having your procedure done? I have been thinking about you and wondering how things were going. I live on the West Coast and my favorite doctor during my treatment had done his training at The Cleveland Clinic. Are you going to have a friend, or family member going with you to your appointment? I always dragged somebody along with me so they could listen and take notes. I was such a basket case, I couldn't remember much of the things that were told to me. Please keep us posted. I will be thinking about you. Remember most of these things turn out to be nothing. You will be in good hands. Prayers and positive thoughts to you. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Asymmetry in the right breast central to the nipple anterior depth

Posts.Content: Kayla, So glad to hear your sister will be with you. I have always had the ultrasound at the same appointment as the spot compression mammogram. I can't imagine they will make you come back for the ultrasound. It is probably why they told you an hour and a half, it makes sense. Time is scheduled for reading the spot compression and enough for the ultrasound. Take care, and I will be thinking about you. Sharon I am just curious did the doctor say what the lesions were on the pancreas? I am just very glad you ended up at the Cleveland Clinic.
Posts.Title: Asymmetry in the right breast central to the nipple anterior depth

Posts.Content: Deannie, I have had breast cancer. I was mis-diagnosed for 7 months. What I learned from the experience is to become my own best advocate. This is your body, your life.... if your little inner voice is telling you something, listen to it. Insist on further diagnostic tests such as an MRI or biopsy. I would be polite, but insistant. You need answers to give you peace of mind. If your doctor will not refer you to a breast center radiologist to do this, get another doctor. Contact your doctor's office today. Good luck and please keep us posted. Hang in there and don't take no for an answer. YOU GO GIRL! Sharon
Posts.Title: breast lump getting bigger

Posts.Content: I think the first thing I would do is get a second opinion. This is, no doubt a huge shock to face at your very young age. On another board, with many young women who have faced the same genetic factors, they have gone through the extensive surgeries. So far, no one has mentioned other extenuating problems because of those surgeries. These genetic tests are both a blessing and a curse. On one hand, they give you a possible look into your health future and let you consider being able to alter having to deal with a fairly deadly type of cancer. It is a sobering look that will have some ramifications and outcomes that greatly impact your life. I wish I could give you more advice than just a relatively pathetic.... get a second opinion. Hopefully, someone with more wisdom than I will respond with more information. Thankfully, you live in or near a very large city with excellent specialists. I guess I wouldn't be making any decision until you have been able to gather a lot more information. I have been through a successful treatment of breast cancer. It is a big plateful in itself but having genetic implications makes breast cancer pale in comparison. Wishing you the very best, and all the positive energy I can send your way. Please keep me posted. Blessings and take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Recently Tested Positive for BRCA1

Posts.Content: After having breast cancer, my best pro-active advice would be anytime you have ANY change in your breast, it is time to get it checked out. Inflammatory breast cancer is one of the nastiest varieties of BC and first signs are changes in the skin. Usually it gets an appearance of orange peel, red, rash, or thickening of the skin. Thankfully, this aggressive form of cancer is one of the more rare types. I have even heard of some doctors, brushing it or messing about with creams to treat the rash.... thinking it is only a rash. I would suggest you put the bug in your doctor's ear and bring up the term inflammatory breast cancer. You may also only have a blood vessel... almost like varicose vein showing through the skin. Do not lose sleep over this as most of these breast things turn out to be a big fat nothing. If it does turn out to be something, best deal with it asap. Good luck to you and keep us posted. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Discoloration on left breast

Posts.Content: It is the call we all dread and fear. Keep in mind the vast majority of these lumps are NOT CANCER! By now you are having the new test so this will be a mute point. Since you have fibrocystic breasts this is something that will continue to happen.... the dreaded call-back. My word of advise from a fellow fibrocyctic breast woman, if there is any question about a lump even after having a mammogram/ultrasound insist on an MRI. I had a questionable area even after having the extra views. The wrong decision allowed my breast cancer diagnosis to be put off for 7 months. An MRI would have diagnosed my breast cancer much sooner. The breast center said their finding didn't warrant an MRI even after my doctor requested one. Sometimes you have to be very pro-active as it can catch cancer much sooner. As for the long wait for appointments or a finding, the thing I do is just know I am doing the right thing and there isn't any more I can do at the moment. I KEEP BUSY and shove the dark thoughts out of my head. Hang in there a please let us know how it turns out. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Got the dreaded callback

Posts.Content: If I were you, I would consult a breast specialist to check this. It could be something as simple as a reaction to fabric softener or laundry detergent. Have you changed any soaps, etc. lately? Can you equate this with that type of change? It also sounds a bit like mastitis which can these types of symptoms. Going to the dark side... it also has symptoms of a very aggressive, but very rare type of breast cancer... inflammatory breast cancer. I urge you to see a breast specialist because many doctor's in a regular practice, even a gyncologist, may not have seen it. No woman is too young to have breast cancer. I rarely write something like this because I know you are already worried and I don't mean to cause you more angst. This just sent off a tiny alarm bell in my head. Please get an appointment & let us know how you are doing. I will love to hear I am completely WRONG. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: its cancer!!!

Posts.Content: They want to do a spot compression which will consist of using a smaller plate for the mammogram machine. They will then do an ultrasound. They are concerned about the asymmetry in your breast and are identifying the location of the area in question. IF there is any question, I would absolutely demand an MRI. This happened to me and it ended up I had breast cancer. I had similar symptoms, and in addition, I had an inverted nipple. It was missed in the spot compression and ultrasound. My diagnosis was delayed until 7 months later, until I felt a lump. My doctor wanted an MRI but the breast center said I did not warrant it. The MRI showed the cancer like a Christmas tree light bulb! I was 59 at the time. My breast was also dense so it had always been diffucult to get a good, clear, mammogram.... another reason I should have had an MRI. I ended up with IDC 2B with 1 positive lymph node. The 7 month delay should not have been.... I know this is terrifying but I want you to learn from my experience. It is best to be on top of things, and a bit demanding. Chances are this will turn out to be nothing. In the case, it might be --something-- believe me, you want to catch it NOW. PLEASE keep us posted. Take care...
Posts.Title: Asymmetry in the right breast central to the nipple anterior depth

Posts.Content: Kayla, I totally understand your concern. It is odd there is such a discrepancy in the two/three sets of films. I would, absolutely, be on the phone for a clarification by your primary care physician. The radiologist can only go by what is seen on the films taken there. If nothing abnormal was seen then the there wasn't a reason for the radiologist to do an ultrasound. I think you are right and correct to question WHY? I also think you were very observant to mention the mammogram taken earlier was more painful. It would make me believe MORE compression was done for the original mammograms. I, too, would question all of it. I have learned to trust my "gut". If it is giving signals, it is best to listen. Please keep us posted. I am very sorry you did not receive the answers you were hoping to get. Hang in there..... take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Asymmetry in the right breast central to the nipple anterior depth

Posts.Content: Kayla, you are so welcome. They will do the spot compression and ultrasound at the same appointment if the place is like a breast center. If they suggest an MRI, you would need a different appointment for that. I haven't heard of fibrous breast being fatty. They are different types of tissue. The fibrous tissue is dense and more difficult for a mammogram to penetrate. Fatty tissue is easier for a mammogram to penetrate. I am glad you have an appointment coming up. Offices are being very proactive so if they suggest a biopsy, try not to worry too much. They are doing this so much now and the majority of these are benign.... not breast cancer. I know it is scary but try not let it consume your life. Hang in there Kayla, you are doing all the right things. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Asymmetry in the right breast central to the nipple anterior depth

Posts.Content: I am so sorry you have joined --the club-- we have millions of members, unfortunately. Having had breast cancer I know a bit about all the emotions and throughts going through your mind. The good thing about breast cancer is the improvements in treatments and outcomes. Progress by leaps and bounds are being made daily. Even in the time since I was treated.... protocols have changed. I had invasive ductal carcinoma a 2.2CM. and one positive sentinal node. I chose to have a mastectomy, but could have had a lumpectomy. I had 4 rounds of chemotherapy and 5 years of follow-up hormone blocking drug. I am cancer free 5 years later. Treatment is no longer the shotgun approach. Pathologists can pin-point at a cellular level and recommend specific treatments because of your unique cancer cells. Women want to know what to expect and that is almost impossible to guess because of the specific treatment that will be just for you. Women also want to know their --survivability-- DON'T GO THERE it is in cold, clinical statistics. When you start reading that, it puts everything on a negative plane. Doctors have to talk in percentages but we were unique individuals. We, as humans, do NOT have an expiration date! I just marched through my treatment with a positive attitude, and a big bucket of humor. I know you are not at that point yet. Once your treatment path is mapped out for you, you WILL feel better. The --unknown-- space you are in right now is a terrifying place. You already KNOW you have breast cancer. Even in that, you no longer need to --worry--. The rest is a process of discovery. You will be able to get through this and hopefully, women on this board can help you.... I know I would. I also went through the preliminary tests.... an MRI, a CT, on and on.... plus a million vials of blood.....arrrrgh. Right now, I wish you a quick passage of time to gather all the facts you need. Be very careful what you read on the internet especially at this particular time in your diagnosis. You don't have enough facts to read something that really applies to you. There are a so many of us breast cancer alumni alive and well today. You can join us!!!! It is a rocky journey but we all make it along that path. Please keep us posted.... I will follow is you reply on this board. You have a whole lot of living to do... you will make it. Hang in there...take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: its cancer!!!

Posts.Content: Mena, You did GOOD GIRL! I am so glad you listened to your --gut-- and got a second and found such a wonderful doctor who you trusted. I think it is amazing how even in the face of a diagnosis of breast cancer, there is good news. Thanks for sharing your story. Great health to you. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Recently Tested Positive for BRCA1

Posts.Content: There is any number of things that cause your lymph nodes to go into action. You will find out and be able to deal with it. Please keep us posted, and many blessings to you. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: A lump under my right armpit

Posts.Content: Did the surgeon drain the cyst by aspirating it? (removing the fluid) So he felt sure that is what it was but was he going to send any to a lab? As for the lymph nodes... the most common place for swollen lymph nodes are the neck, armpit, and groin. Have you had any virus/cold lately? It might be mono or even an indication of Lyme Disease. I would keep an eye on the lymph nodes just to see if they enlarge. If so, I would check with your regular doctor. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: A lump under my right armpit

Posts.Content: I am so sorry to hear this was the news you received.... it is a total shock to say the least. I also had the same type of cancer 5 years ago. I chose to have a mastectomy but I could have had a lumpectomy. I went to an oncologist for a consultation and then went to a surgeon who was a breast specialist. She was a young woman and I was so pleased with her care. I don't know if you live in the U.S. but if you do or have any say in the matter, I would recommend getting a referral to a surgeon who specializes in breast surgery. Sometimes there are women's center's where you would find a breast cancer specialist. I had a medical oncologist and I felt I received great care. I had 4 rounds of AC chemotherapy. Treatments have changed even in the 5 years since my BC. Diagnostics have become even more sensitive and treatment even in women with the same diagnosis will be different. You have the most common type of breast cancer so there is a lot known about how it is acts and how to treat it. Hopefully, your cancer will be ER+ PR+ Her2- which means your cancer's cells feed off of hormones. Mine was and I am taking a hormone blocking drug. So far, it doesn't sound like you have received this information yet. You may have to have several more baseline tests... such an an MRI, or PET Scan, a bone scan, MUGA, and about 50 gallons of blood.... or so it seems. You already have a lot of information but you still have more discovery to take place. It is not uncommon to feel like you are walking around in a fog. Life around you almost feels unreal. You go to the grocery store and you see people just going through their day and you have just heard you have breast cancer. Please know, breast cancer is not a death sentence! It's not fun but you get through it and come out the other side a much stronger women for the experience. I would advise you to try to contact a support group. The other thing I did not do was keep it a secret. Don't be surprised when you tell people you get "THE LOOK." I had one person ask me how long did I have to live? Arrrrgh. You WILL live. If somebody starts telling you awful stories... stop them instantly. You only want to hear of positive outcomes. You will imagine your own horror movies in your head. It's a rocky road but you will get through this. There are millions of us women out here alive and well after treatment. Again, I would advise you to try to get to a specialist in breast cancer surgery. They could also give you the best options for reconstruction if you choose to have that too. I wish you the very best and want you to know you will be OK. My life is completely normal and I will complete my 5 year hormone blocking drug regime in January. I hope you keep us posted and let us know how you are doing. I wish you hadn't joined...."The Club" but you have lots of "sisters" out there. Heck.... even my poor brother-in-law was diagnosed with invasive ductal breast cancer last Christmas. He, too, is doing great. He had a mastectomy and did not require any further treatment because it was a very low grade with a zero chance of reoccurance according to his oncoDX test. Hang in there darlin' you will be OK. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Wow - Its cancer!

Posts.Content: Well, more good news.... this is one breast. This is a typical recommendation for surgery when there are two spots in one breast.... mastectomy. Chemo depends on more pathology reports.... your age, stage, size, is it ER+ PR+ Her2- aggressiveness of the tumors or grade, lymph node involvement, and also an oncoDX test. The last one can predict if this is the type of cancer that might reocur in the future. The oncoDX test takes 2 to 3 weeks to get back after the surgery is completed too. So there are more labs you have to wait for until you know if you will have to have chemo. Have a chat with your doctor about what he thinks your chances of having chemo are. They usually have a feel for what is going to happen. I had cancer 5 years ago and even in that short amount of time there have been changes in protocol for treatment. I wish I could give you a better guess but every woman's case is unique to her and the types of cells in her tumor. I would say to you.... "So far, so good." IDC is the most common form of breast cancer.... and if you were to be ER+ PR+ Her2- I'd say a big YAHOO for you. What those letters stand for is the type of breast cancer cells that feed off of hormones. You can literally starve any free floating cells by cutting of their hormones by taking a hormone blocking drug for 5 years.... like I have done. So... you are still waiting for more pieces of the puzzle. So glad you had an MRI because that shows up other spots of cancer that would be in the other breast or chest or large area's of lymph nodes if they were involved. What I am about to tell you about my experience with a mastectomy is one side of a spectrum. I had the mastectomy, had 5 sentinel lymph nodes removed. I woke up from the surgery, laughing with the nurses in the recovery room. They put me in my room, I spent the night, eat like a horse and no pain. I never took one pain pill because I never had one tiny little tweak of discomfort. I had a drain in that was taken out after about 10 days. For me.... I know this isn't common but I had no pain. I was up and about doing the dishes, in about two days because I was sleepy from the anesthesia. I really don't know what the down time is because I just didn't have much. The drain is kind of a pain to have to deal with beause it has to be emptied but I thought it was very easy. That is NOT to say other women don't have discomfort. I would think your real down time would be about 10 days or until you get the drain removed. As for reconstruction.... there are a couple of different procedures. The most common is after your mastectomy, a tissue expander is placed. Slowly over the next few months, tissue is expanded until there is enough to place an implant. I didn't opt for reconstruction so what I am sharing is from other women who have had this done. Your reconstructive surgeon will be able to give you the best information. The women I know who have had this done are happy with the outcome. One more thing... since you are going to have a mastectomy, you will not have to go through radiation treatment... which is good. It can be many daily appointments over a series of weeks and it can be pretty tough on your skin. Please keep me posted... I am so glad to hear from you. Yes... you have breast cancer but you are GOING TO BE OK!!! Hang in there, and I will share any information I can with you. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Wow - Its cancer!

Posts.Content: I am SOOOOOOO happy for you! Most of these things actually do turn out to be something other than breast cancer. I am absolutely thrilled and know you feel like a huge black cloud has moved away. Go live your wonderful life!!! Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Worried

Posts.Content: It is my guess a bi-lateral mastectomy for your situation is fairly common. I belong to another breast cancer board and it comes up quite often. I would share the board's name with you except I would get kicked off of this board if I dared mention it. What happens, a woman will have a profilactic bi-lateral mastectomy after finding breast cancer in one. At the time of the pathology dissection of the second breast, they find a small cancer hiding in that one. DCIS is a pre-cancerous or stage 0 cancer condition, which is a pre-curser to invasive ductal carcinoma as you probably know. You have a grand opportunity to prevent the full blown cancer with all its ramifications. Your long term estrogen therapy may have been a contributing factor your situation at present. I was also a longterm estrogen patient. You may have some hot flashes with the withdrawal from your hormone therapy but only time will tell. It is something I have now had to live with for Y-E-A-R-S. I have more to tell you but have to take our little doggy to the vet right now. I will get back to you asap. Hopefully, you will have more responders. My opinions are only that.... just sharing my experience with breast cancer and having made a boatload of friends with various types of breast cancers. I will leave you with the thought, for having breast cancer or the pre.... you are in a good place. All of this, so far, is the earliest of stages. A big YAHOO for you. I wish all women would find their cancers as you have. Will type later.... Sharon
Posts.Title: NEW Bilateral breast cancer

Posts.Content: Again.... hang in there. I will be anxious to hear. I know how terrifying this is because one hears about breast cancer ALL THE TIME. Big positive hugs to you. Please keep me posted. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Linear calcification and biopsy results tomorrow

Posts.Content: I have had several friends who have had biopsy's for this condition. A couple have turned out to be DCIS which is a pre-cancerous condition. They were both staged at Stage 0. One was in my best friend who is 12 years out now and the other is in a woman in her early 40's just completing treatment. I can imagine why they moved up your appointment but I would also be suspicious. I know right now you are sick with worry but you will get the information you need tomorrow. I wish there was something I could do to help you at this point. You will be ok, no matter what. I don't know how old you are (or young) but I have had lots more friends have this be totally benign and only two with the test coming back positive. Hang in there.... I have had breast cancer and just returned from my check up with my oncologist today. 5 years cancer free. Mine was early stage and breast cancer and its isn't what it used to be. Again... hang in there gal, you will be ok. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Linear calcification and biopsy results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Have you had a chance to talk with your oncologist yet? You are still in the diagnosis stage and the good thing this was discovered before you had symptoms. This is attached to your spine and not in the spine, itself. I am not a doctor but just wandering my way through your description. What I am about to say is just a guess... when breast cancer metastasizes, it usually starts in an organ or IN your spine. On an x-ray, the bone would have a dark look to it as the bone starts to deteriorate. Your radiologist and oncologist need to look at any studies you had done that show this area BEFORE you were treated for BC. I think at this point, your oncologist will order more testing to determine what this is. This is probably a straight forward protocol at this point. It is probably going to be treated in one or all of 3 ways.... surgery, chemo (if it is determined to be mets.) and radiation. I can imagine your absolute fear because those of us who have been treated for breast cancer live under the threat of mets ALL the time. I totally understand how you are desperately searching for answers right now and I wish I had real concrete information to give you. You WILL find out what this is and be treated for it asap. You are just extremely lucky this was found at this point. You can thank your COPD. Please keep us posted... I feel your fear, Debi. Hang in there and many blessings to you. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Breast cancer metastasis in Spine

Posts.Content: Soyaandpepper: One more thing... DON'T go wandering the internet reading stories, it will only terrify you. Lots of it is out of date, not factual, really doesn't pertain to you, etc. Stay off the internet and do something fun like retail therapy. Again.... positive thoughts going your way. Sharon
Posts.Title: just had a core needle biopsy 1 2

Posts.Content: Congrats on the weight loss! I just don't have a clue about the breast tissue but I sure don't think it has anything to do with breast cancer. It is, no doubt, more to do with excess skin now that you have lost a lot of weight. I think a person would find the same thing happening to any part of their body where there was a lot of weight loss. You just don't need all that excess skin to cover what is no longer there. You might have a consult with a plastic surgeon if it continues to bother you. I just wouldn't worry about this being anything to worry about except esthetically. Sharon
Posts.Title: Breast Skin Feels Paper thin--Help

Posts.Content: In agreement with the other's. Please see your doctor immediately. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Left armpit and breast swollen and painful

Posts.Content: I am glad you do not have to wait any longer. Blessings & Big hugs, Sharon
Posts.Title: Worried

Posts.Content: This happens like a bolt out of the blue. We, as women, think about the possibility but never think we will be the one.... until we are. This discovery then pushes us to make decisions rather quickly. I truly believe you are on the right track and support your plans... as terrifying as they are right now. Your decision to find the best plastic surgeon for those new ta-ta's is really such a positive move. You can also get a second opinion about all of it too. Ask your doctor if he/she plans to do an Onco DX Test? This is a specialized test that can tell how aggressive or likely this cancer is to come back at a future time. This can also be another tool to help you and your oncologist make a decision about a possible course of chemotherapy. The treatment for breast cancer is made on looking at each woman's cancer in it's individual cells. No longer is there just a shotgun approach to treatment. Every woman's cancer is different on a cellular level even if the type of cancer is the same. You already have a bunch of information just from the biopsy's you have had. The rest of the picture becomes totally clear with the pathology report. Sometimes when women have a bi-lateral mastectomy, more cancer is found in a different part of the breast where it hadn't showed on the mammogram. Have you had an MRI or has it been suggested? So often, an MRI can pick up very small cancers that a mammogram missed. I have been thinking about you today and hoping you are doing ok... mentally.... This is a very difficult time.... actually, in a way, things get easier once you get all the testing back and are set on a course of treatment. At least then... you know what the plan is. This all is just my experience and friends of mine I have made over the past 5 years. There are a lot of us breast cancer folks out here. We have a very large sisterhood. More and more is being discovered for diagnosis at earlier stages, and better treatments. I hope you keep me posted. You will do fine....you will live, and you will become a much stronger woman for having to walk this path. Huge healing hugs, sister, and take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: NEW Bilateral breast cancer

Posts.Content: I have had only a single mastectomy so do not qualify for the actual experience pool you are requesting. I would like to say I am very sorry to hear about this diagnosis.... there are so many breast cancer folks our here. Believe me, I know how frightened you are. Keep in the front of your mind.... these are early, early, cancers. Standing on the outside, I can see many things that are in your favor. Even in a diagnosis of breast cancer, you have many silver linings regarding your story. Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common form of breast cancer and therefore, has almost a standarised treatment. You have a much less aggressive form of cancer, which will probably turn out to be ER+ PR+ Her2- another good for you. You don't know if you will have to go through chemotherapy but probably no radiation because you are having a double mastectomy. Here is where age is a good thing.... post menopausal disease more in your favor. The only negative I can throw in is the expanders for the reconstruction cause pain. Universally, this is the same story from every woman having reconstruction, expanders hurt. I think as you go along in your journey, as you gather more pieces of the puzzle of your personal disease, you will become less fearful. It is a long road to be endured but every procedure you go through will be one less and one closer step to getting back to your normal life. Being that diagnostics have become so much better, each woman's treatment is a bit different from somebody else's. Protocols look at individual cancer cells when determining a diagnosis. At this point, what you have had for your diagnosis so far I would be out and celebrating. Keep in mind, if you get a response from a woman who has had exactly the same diagnosis, how her body responds, could be completely different than how you may respond. Having been on another board, this is a universal plea. Women want to know how they are going to feel and what it is going to be like. Unfortunately, we are all different. We can all tell you of our experience and yours will turn out to be something different. You will be ok. As you go along, you will gain more information about your diagnosis and knowledge will take the place of fear. Hang in there and much good luck to you. Sharon
Posts.Title: NEW Bilateral breast cancer

Posts.Content: First I think you are doing the right thing getting it checked. I can't begin to guess what it could be but be sure to describe it just as you have here. With a family history of breast cancer, you can't help but be concerned about that. As humans, we naturally go --to the dark side-- and scare ourselves too. I hope your doctor doesn't blow you off.... if he/she does, can you get a second opinion from another doctor? If after your appointment, you still don't feel good about the answer you get, I hope you can get a second opinion. You ARE doing what you should be doing. I hope you let us know how it goes at the doc's office. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Right armpit lump + right arm pain

Posts.Content: So glad to hear a reason and lessoning of symptoms. Most of the time, these turn out to be lots of other things that have nothing to do with cancer. We are bombarded with tales of woe, articles about breast cancer, TV warnings about breast cancer so of course, cancer, is the first thing that pops into our minds. It is great you were able to get in to see a doctor who was able to diagnoses what was going on. Thank you for letting us know. I hope you NEVER, EVER, EVER, have to visit here again with worries about breast cancer. Tuck this into your memory bank though..... breast cancer is a disease which is highly curable/treatable when caught early. So, if you find something weird going on in your breast, be sure to check with your doctor ASAP. I was one who did that and had treatment and am 5 years down the road without cancer. It is bad enough to be diagnosed with breast cancer but to be diagnosed with late stage breast cancer is a shame. Take care, and good health to you! Sharon
Posts.Title: Right armpit lump + right arm pain

Posts.Content: Quote: Originally Posted by FM927 Serene, what you are really looking for is a second opinion on the interpretations of what the biopsy shows! I did exactly this and I chose the surgeon who made me feel that she really cared about my situation and advised me as what what would be better for me in the long run! all the best to you, Mena This was my point originally. The cancer diagnosis is there but what you eventually do with the BTCA1 is at question. Thank you Mena for putting it in better words. Sharon
Posts.Title: Recently Tested Positive for BRCA1

Posts.Content: Soyaandpepper: I think it was very, very, brilliant to be sooo on the ball about the health care decisions you make. When that little voice inside starts saying "This just doesn't sound right" it is best to listen. I am glad you are in the care of a breast surgeon, this is where you needed to be. Core/needle biopsy's are state of the art. You did good girl! . Now.... the wait. Arrrrgh I hate the wait. So many of these things come back benign. My advice is try not to go over the top with worry. I don't know anything else about your suspicious bumps and hope the tests come back as ok. Hang in there.... lots of us here have been through this procedure and it sounds, to me, you have done the right and correct thing. Please keep us posted... I know what it is like to wait. Doctors are so aware of litigation, they biopsy nearly everything. Again, hang in there.... Please let us know how it all turns out.... we know what it's like. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: just had a core needle biopsy 1 2

Posts.Content: I completely agree with dbcataula12. If the creams have not helped, and it is getting larger, please go in an have this area checked. I would even go as far as to ask for a biopsy of that tissue. Don't allow a doctor to --guess-- what it might be and then call that good. Only a biopsy, checking those cells will tell you exactly. IBC wouldn't necessarily show up on a mammogram so that is why I would be pushing for a biopsy. After having been through breast cancer which was missed, sometimes you have to shove your own way through the medical system. You really need to be your own best advocate. Much luck to you and keep us posted. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Red Spot somewhat concerned about IBC

Posts.Content: Wendy, first ... IBC is a very rare type of breast cancer. Hopefully by now, you have been able to get in to see a surgeon. How are you doing and what did the surgeon have to say? Breast cancer can happen to anyone.... no rhyme or reason to it, unfortunately. You have done all the correct things by having this checked out and proceeding with further testing. Lots of women have abnormal breast things show up and so many of these are nothing.... or something other than breast cancer. Please let us know how you are doing. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Breast cancer scare... IBC?

Posts.Content: Well, we are --nearly-- sisters. I had the same diagnosis. My primary care doctor said to me.... "At least you have the good kind of breast cancer." So far he has been correct. It sounds like you are in wonderful hands too. You keep your positive attitude as it will take you a long way. Honestly, there are things about your diagnosis you can celebrate and be happy for. Isn't it odd, even in breast cancer there are things you are happy to hear..... like YOUR diagnosis!!! You GO GIRL! I hope you keep in touch. You WILL BE OK. Hang in there, take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Wow - Its cancer!

Posts.Content: Arrrrgh! The waiting is the worst. I am very glad he referred you to a surgeon. Usually what happens in these things they do a needle biopsy but that will depend on what the radiologist who reads the mammogram has to say. The reason why the emergency room doc put you on antibiotics was just in case it might be mastitis... an inflammatory process in milk ducts. If the report comes back.... "Wait 6 months... and then do another mammogram" I would seriously question that. Myself, having had breast cancer, I want to KNOW what that thing is and the only way to do it is with a needle or core biopsy. Since this is solid.... I really want to know what it is. Now after I say all of that awful stuff.... I want to "back up the train" and say lots of these things turn out to be just plain nothing. I also question why this surgeon will be cutting it out as a needle biopsy would give you the results you are looking for. I kind of think the ER doc is guessing that it will be removed. If I were you, I would take some over the counter pain medication for your breast. You might also see if a cold pack might help... if not, try heat. Please keep me posted.... and thanks to your hubby for getting you right in to an ER. You are doing all you can right now.... making yourself sick with worry won't help. I know it is easy for me to say but I have been there.... done that. Hang in there, take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Worried

Posts.Content: I would absolutely contact the oncologist because he can refer you to a different surgeon who can probably get you in much quicker. The oncologist can also tell you the what the outcome of your mammogram it too. Never take you-have-to-wait-until-the-24th.... there are a ton of other doctors you can get in previous to have to wait that long. I feel really bad for people when they take what they can get.... you be your own BEST advocate!
