I was always nice, polite, had a big sense of humor BUT.... when it comes to your healthcare, you are the most important person in the world to you. Call the oncologist today or tomorrow and tell them the situation. They can refer you to someone else and BTW..... what WAS seen on the mammogram??? You GO GIRL! You be strong, polite, but you need an appointment. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Worried

Posts.Content: Debi, I am really glad you wrote back... at least you know where this is locate. It is my guess but I think the referral to the neurosurgeon is because of the close proximity to your spine. They probably want to get you in the hands of a specialist who knows the spinal chord inside and out! I think that is an extremely smart referral by the oncologist. As for the time line.... asap is just how you want it too. It remains a waiting game for the tests to get back. I remain happy this didn't go to the point of symptoms and also it is between the lungs and the spine. As far as I am trying to picture this, whatever this turns out to be, it sounds like it was caught quickly. As far as a biopsy.... not knowing exactly where this is it is probably nowhere a surgeon could even get a needle. I wouldn't be surprised it they neurosurgeon, in doing the biopsy, removed the entire mass which will be GREAT. PLEASE keep me posted. I have been thinking about you and wondering how it was going. I am glad you have not had to wait weeks and weeks. Hang in there darlin' prayers and positive thoughts going your way. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Breast cancer metastasis in Spine

Posts.Content: THIS IS FABULOUS NEWS!!!! I am thrilled for you...thank God. Thanks for letting all of us know. I am sure you feel as if the weight of the world has been lifted off your shoulders, I know that would be my feeling. Take care..... watch that COPD and LIVE a fabulous life! Hugs, Sharon
Posts.Title: Breast cancer metastasis in Spine

Posts.Content: I have never heard of this type of breast cancer metastsizing. Your radiologist IS telling the truth, and in your age bracket is when I have heard of this showing up. This is exactly what mammograms are supposed to catch. Again, I have had many pals who have had these microcalcifications show up and they have been benign. More than have been malignant. I want to you to contact me when you get back from your appointment. Honestly, I wish the ob/gyn office had not made this such a drama for you. Hang in there and I will be waiting to hear from you. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Linear calcification and biopsy results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Oh darlin' I am sorry for this news BUT even in a diagnosis of breast cancer this is GOOD NEWS! This IS early stage cancer and there are treatments galore to cure you. I also had invasive ductal carcinoma.... THE MOST COMMON FORM OF BREAST CANCER! About 80% breast cancers are invasive so they know the most about these types. They will stage your cancer, and your treatment will be tailored just for you. They have the ability to look at individual cells. It is like they can look into a crystal ball! No two women have the same type of treatment because these cells are so individual. I chose to have a mastectomy with no reconstruction (I could have had a lumpectomy). I was and am happy with my decision. It is just a personal decision you can talk over with your surgeon. I am very glad to hear you are set with insurance and sick time. That can be such a huge source of worry. How wonderful they brought in a bus for mobile mammograms. You will probably end up being "poster girl" for finding breast cancer at early stage. You are going to be ok, you are NOT going to die! Be prepared when you tell your friends, co-workers, and relatives about this. Lots of them are going to give you "The Pity Look." They will be thinking you're a goner. Do NOT listen to negative stories. Stop people from telling you about Aunt Betty who died.... You are NOT Aunt Betty and breast cancer treatment in this day and age are not the same as in "Aunt Betty's Day." Be careful about going to different sites and reading about breast cancer. The one referred for you to read is a good one! Be careful, because some of these sites will only scare and depress you. Please, please, keep in mind, this is where doctor's want to find BC, at this very early stage. You WILL be one of the survivors! I have walked the path you are on right now. You be brave, and realize there are ba-zillions of women who have been there, done that. You WILL be ok. I hope we can keep in contact and don't be afraid to ask any of your doctors if you have questions. I am sorry to hear about the diagnosis but very thrilled to hear what it is and at such an early stage. Like my doctor told me, "Yes you have breast cancer but you have the good kind." Your son sounds like he is also in a good place and has worked very hard. You are his Mom who knows what is best for him. Hang in there, God will always be next to you. Big huge healing hugs, you will be ok. Please keep in touch. God's blessings, Sharon
Posts.Title: Linear calcification and biopsy results tomorrow

Posts.Content: I am glad my bla-bla has helped. It is just from my experience and knowing a lot of women who are ALL ALIVE today after going through breast cancer. As you go along, you will actually become less anxious. It sounds really odd, but as you see your treatment path laid out in front of you, the terror of the unknown will melt away. You actually already have a lot more information as to what you have. My advise to you as you start out.... get a large 3 ring binder and a hole punch. Get business cards from each of the offices you visit and tape them on the inside of the cover. ASK FOR COPIES OF EVERY TEST YOU GET. They have to give them to you and are usually happy to. Put them in the binder and carry that thing with you to every appointment. You will be surprised how often you have to leaf through it to share some information from one office to another. It saves a lot of time and each office will have all of your information always at hand. ALWAYS be polite and pleasent but be your own best advocate. Question something that doesn't sound right. Ask for clarification. Doctor's/nurses make mistakes, you have to be on top of your game and be your best advocate. As you go to these first information appointments, take a family member or a good friend with you to take notes and LISTEN. Your head will be swimming with the information and the understandable fear you will have. You will forget half of the stuff so you really need to have someone help you remember what the doctor told you. You just put on your big girl panties and march right through this challenge. I can assure you, you will be a much stronger women for the experience. I know you would much rather be doing anything else but for some reason this is what's in your life plan. You WILL get through this, and you WILL BE OK! You will join your other "sister's" and beat this disease.... I have no doubt. You got a lot of company out here. If you need any information I would certainly try to share what I know or point you in the right direction. Hang in there, gal. God will always be there for you. Take care, and big huge healing hugs, Sharon
Posts.Title: Linear calcification and biopsy results tomorrow

Posts.Content: I am very glad you are getting this looked at so quickly at least for your peace of mind. This will probably turn out to be (in the big picture) no big deal. Hang in there, and take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Left armpit and breast swollen and painful

Posts.Content: IBC is a very rare type of breast cancer but it is always best to get these things checked out. You have got enough on your plate with your husband in the hospital. I am really happy to hear you are going to push for an earlier appointment with a breast specialist. Hang in there and please let us know what you hear. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Red Spot somewhat concerned about IBC

Posts.Content: Tammy, my advice to you is to get in and have this checked as soon as you can, which it sounds like you are trying to do. We could all guess as to what this is but nobody knows until you get a mammogram and see a doctor and that is pretty much the bottom line. Contact the American Cancer Society, Planned Parenthood, and Susan G. Komen Foundation. Between these organizations, you should be able to, at least, get a free mammogram. I completely understand your sense of fear. Chances are it will turn out to be something other than breast cancer. BUT.....if it is, you want to get it diagnosed as soon as possible. Hang in there and take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Worried

Posts.Content: I have had breast cancer 5 years ago and it was invasive ductal carcinoma. It was stage 2B with one positive lymph node. Even though I was regular with mammograms and SBE, my cancer wasn't discovered until it had gotten this far. You are in a unique position to save yourself from a much tougher more advanced invasive cancer. If it were me, knowing what I know now, I would have the bi-lateral mastectomy & reconstruction. Good luck to you and take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: NEW Bilateral breast cancer

Posts.Content: Dang... how did I miss all that??? It was late last night... Another word of warning be careful what you read on the internet. I scared myself to badly reading some of it, I had to quit. Again, I can't mention sites to go visit but good information is out there. Most of the women who are battling this disease and in the fight of their lives are much younger women with aggressive disease. There are things to be thankful for even in a diagnosis of cancer.... intermediate grade, hormone positive, post-menopausal, small, early stage. Hang in there, you will be ok. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: NEW Bilateral breast cancer

Posts.Content: I am SO happy you went ahead and had it checked. I have been thinking about you and glad you got in so quickly. Hopefully, this will get cleared up with the new cream. IBC is really rare but you are really on top of this. THANKS for letting us know. THis will probably end up being just a blip in the pathway of life. Keep us posted. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Red Spot somewhat concerned about IBC

Posts.Content: Wendy, that is a huge relief! Be sure to go back for your check in 6 months. You did the best thing getting it checked out quickly. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Breast cancer scare... IBC?

Posts.Content: I am very sorry you are so worried, but I completely understand your concern. Has anyone suggested you get an MRI or another biopsy? MRI's are great for picking up things that mammograms and ultrasound's can't. I have had 3 friends have spots of calcium show up on mammogram's and 2 out of 3 were benign. The 3rd one had DCIS. I would think about getting a second opinion about this lump. It is never a bad thing to be thorough. Most of these lumps are totally benign... in fact the vast majority of them. For your own peace of mind get it checked out again. This is not a fun way to live! Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Lump since breastfeeding, ultrasound/mammogram clear

Posts.Content: Wow.... what a story. If you think about it, your Mom was a bit of a pioneer in the world of breast cancer treatment. I am sure she is terrified and you are too. There has been so much discovered in the years since your Mom's cancer treatment and a ton of stuff to help get her through this more recent diagnosis. So glad she went in to have it checked by her doctor. I have heard of breast cancer reocurring on the scar from breast cancer surgery so anything is possible. I would have a positive feeling about this and even though it is a reocurrance, much can be done. Prayers for your dear Mom and for you too. She is lucky to have such a loving daughter. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: my mom recurrence after 35 years!!!!

Posts.Content: I JUST read you are going to have the MRI. Thank goodness.... I will be praying this is all for nothing. Hang in there.... please keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Abnormal mammo, sched. breast MRI to rule out lobular cancer?? Help!

Posts.Content: PLEASE get an MRI. This is extremely important. There could be a ba-zillion different reasons for your breast to feel and be the way it is right now. You are only interested in ruling out the only important reason.... lobular breast cancer. You should not put this off as if this is something serious, you have got to catch it asap. It is so understandable to want to find reasons why you can put it off.... the money, it's nothing, it's my bra etc. This is nothing to mess with... I have to get an MRI yearly. It is always out of pocket because of a huge deductable. You can shop around and find a much less expensive cost. Honestly, when it comes to MRI's just like shoes.... get on the phone and start shopping! You can also arrange a payment schedule.... just as I have done. My husband and I are retired. We do not have medicare, we have to buy a very expensive catastrophic health insurance so we have had to do our own shopping. Get busy and do this asap. This is your life, and you have babies to take care of. Please keep us posted. Take care...
Posts.Title: Abnormal mammo, sched. breast MRI to rule out lobular cancer?? Help!

Posts.Content: Thank God! SO glad to hear..... the majority of times these DO come back as benign. Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Abnormal mammo, sched. breast MRI to rule out lobular cancer?? Help!

Posts.Content: An hypoechoic mass CAN be benign too. If you have concerns.... PLEASE contact the office. This is when you --inner voice-- is telling you, you need more information. ASK FOR A COPY OF THE TEST RESULTS. Just from my life experience, and having had breast cancer, I have grown a lot more bold. Since you have very dense breast tissue it is difficult to get a clear, diagnostic image. Digital Mammograms have made improvements but your breasts are going to add to the difficulty of diagnostics. Do not be afraid to ask for further diagnostics to put your mind to rest and to be your own best advocate. As scary as it is to be a bit more aggressive, you are taking the best care of yourself you can. Being that it has not become larger, and that it is a well circumscribed mass sounds like it means it is not irregular... irregular masses could be an indication of cancer. My lump felt like cauliflower under my skin. The edges were irregular. Please, contact the radiologist, your doctor, or the office who did the ultrasound. You need to have your mind put to rest about this. Never be afraid to ask for further testing such as an MRI. The MRI was the test that really showed what was up with my mass along with a needle biopsy. Since your lump is the size of a pea.... this is very small. Call asap to get more information. You GO girl! Take care, Sharon
Posts.Title: Please help me understand an ultrasound report

Posts.Content: I am glad to hear you got the MRI. Please remember, most of these come back benign. You can also CALL THE OFFICE to see if the MRI has been read. Please let us know. Take care...
Posts.Title: Abnormal mammo, sched. breast MRI to rule out lobular cancer?? Help!
